edu.berkeley.compbio.sequtils.strings
Class MarkovTreeNode

java.lang.Object
  com.davidsoergel.dsutils.AbstractGenericFactoryAware
      edu.berkeley.compbio.sequtils.strings.MarkovTreeNode
All Implemented Interfaces:
com.davidsoergel.dsutils.GenericFactoryAware, com.davidsoergel.dsutils.Labellable<String>, com.davidsoergel.stats.MutableDistribution, edu.berkeley.compbio.ml.cluster.AdditiveClusterable<MarkovTreeNode>, edu.berkeley.compbio.ml.cluster.Clusterable<MarkovTreeNode>, SequenceSpectrum<MarkovTreeNode>, Cloneable
Direct Known Subclasses:
RonPSANode
public class MarkovTreeNode
extends com.davidsoergel.dsutils.AbstractGenericFactoryAware
implements SequenceSpectrum<MarkovTreeNode>, com.davidsoergel.stats.MutableDistribution

A node in a tree where each transition is labeled by a byte and has a local probability (that is, conditional on the parent node). If the tree is completely filled out with respect to its alphabet up to a depth k, then it represents a k-order Markov model. If it is incompletely filled out, it may represent a Variable Memory Markov model (VMM).

Version:
$Id: MarkovTreeNode.java 519 2009-10-08 07:01:28Z soergel $
Author:
David Soergel
See Also:

This class should not be used to represent a Probabilistic Suffix Tree, because that is likely to be confusing.

public com.davidsoergel.stats.Multinomial<Byte> getProbs()

fragmentLogProbability

public double fragmentLogProbability(SequenceFragment sequenceFragment,
                                     boolean perSample)
                              throws SequenceSpectrumException
Computes the total log probability of generating the given sequence fragment under the model. This differs from totalProbability(byte[]) in that the sequence fragment is not given explicitly but only as metadata. Thus its probability may be computed from summary statistics that are already available in the given SequenceFragment rather than from the raw sequence. Also, because these probabilities are typically very small, the result is returned in log space (indeed implementations will likely compute them in log space).

Specified by:
fragmentLogProbability in interface SequenceSpectrum<MarkovTreeNode>
Parameters:
sequenceFragment - the SequenceFragment whose probability is to be computed
perSample - normalize the probability by the number of samples found in the SequenceFragment, i.e., take the geometric mean
Returns:
the natural logarithm of the conditional probability (a double value between 0 and 1, inclusive)
Throws:
SequenceSpectrumException

getMaxDepth

public int getMaxDepth()
Careful-- this gets cached on the first call so will be invalid later if the tree is changed

Specified by:
getMaxDepth in interface SequenceSpectrum<MarkovTreeNode>
Returns:

setIgnoreEdges

public void setIgnoreEdges(boolean ignoreEdges)
Description copied from interface: SequenceSpectrum
Specify whether or not this sequence spectrum attempts to account for edge effects, i.e. the first and last words of each sequence. Accounting for these properly introduces a good deal of complexity and requires extra time, so considering spectra to describe biases is infinitely long sequn

Specified by:
setIgnoreEdges in interface SequenceSpectrum<MarkovTreeNode>
Parameters:
ignoreEdges - the ignoreEdges
See Also:
FirstWordProvider

setImmutable

public void setImmutable()
Description copied from interface: SequenceSpectrum
Declare that this spectrum should not change anymore. In practice this is not enforced; this is used only to free up memory by forgetting data that would be needed to recompute the spectrum if it were to change.

Specified by:
setImmutable in interface SequenceSpectrum<MarkovTreeNode>

spectrumEquals

public boolean spectrumEquals(SequenceSpectrum spectrum)
Test whether the given sequence statistics are equivalent to this one. Differs from equals() in that implementations of this interface may contain additional state which make them not strictly equal; here we're only interested in whether they're equal as far as this interface is concerned.

Naive implementations will simply test for exact equality; more sophisticated implementations ought to use a more rigorous idea of "statistically equivalent", though in that case we'll probabably need to provide more parameters, such as a p-value threshold to use. Note that the spectra know the number of samples used to generate them, so at least that's covered.

Specified by:
spectrumEquals in interface SequenceSpectrum<MarkovTreeNode>
Parameters:
spectrum - the SequenceSpectrum to compare
Returns:
True if the spectra are equivalent, false otherwise

copyProbsFromSpectrumRecursively

public void copyProbsFromSpectrumRecursively(SequenceSpectrum spectrum)
Recursively fills out the tree so that each node has either a complete set of children or none at all, and assigns conditional probabilities according to the given spectrum. That is: if this node has any children, ensures that there is a child for each symbol in the alphabet.

fragmentLogProbabilityFromIntKcount

public double fragmentLogProbabilityFromIntKcount(SequenceFragment sequenceFragment)
                                           throws SequenceSpectrumException
Computes the total log probability of generating the given sequence fragment under the model. This differs from totalProbability(byte[]) in that the sequence fragment is not given explicitly but only as metadata. Thus its probability may be computed from summary statistics that are already available in the given SequenceFragment rather than from the raw sequence. Also, because these probabilities are typically very small, the result is returned in log space (indeed implementations will likely compute them in log space).

Parameters:
sequenceFragment - the SequenceFragment whose probability is to be computed
Returns:
the natural logarithm of the conditional probability (a double value between 0 and 1, inclusive)
Throws:
SequenceSpectrumException
